conclusion: To determine if the difference in speed between the two objects, A and B, is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of both objects.
The velocity of object A is given by the slope of the curve for A.
The velocity of object B is given by the slope of the curve for B.
The difference in speed between the two objects at any time t is given by |v_A(t) - v_B(t)|.
To find if this difference is continuously increasing, we need to analyze the rate of change of this difference.

The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration. If the slope is positive, the acceleration is positive (the object is speeding up). If the slope is negative, the acceleration is negative (the object is slowing down).
From the graph, we can see that the slope of the curve for A is decreasing and becomes zero at t1.
This means that the acceleration of A is decreasing and becomes zero at t1.
The slope of the curve for B is also decreasing and becomes zero at t1.
This means that the acceleration of B is decreasing and becomes zero at t1.

Since both objects have decreasing accelerations and both start from rest, the object with the larger initial acceleration will have a larger velocity at any given time t until their velocities become equal.
From the graph, we can see that the initial acceleration of A is greater than the initial acceleration of B.
Therefore, the velocity of A will be greater than the velocity of B for a certain period of time.
As the accelerations of both objects decrease and become zero at t1, the difference in their velocities will decrease until they become equal at t1.
The difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
It starts to increase as the velocities of the objects differ, but it will eventually decrease as the velocities become equal at t1.
Therefore, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
